Welcome to the @global.prog_name programme!

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting children and families in your community.

@global.prog_name is a group-based family strengthening programme for families with children and teens ages 2 to 17. 
It has been designed specifically with the goal of promoting positive parent-child relationships to reduce the risk of physical and emotional child abuse and neglect in the communities.

The overall goal of @global.prog_name is to provide parents with the skills to promote healthy child development, learning, and wellbeing. We achieve this goal by improving the following: 

- **Parent sense of responsibility and commitment**: Recognise and embrace their essential role in raising children.

- **Parenting knowledge, skill, and sense of competence**: Gaining practical skills and confidence in parenting

- **Parent knowledge in child development**: Understanding key stages of child development and age-appropriate needs.

- **Positive parenting behaviour**: Encouraging nurturing, respectful, and supportive interactions.

- **Positive, consistent discipline strategies**: Using calm, constructive, and consistent discipline.

- **Parental supervision of children**: Ensuring safe, attentive, and appropriate supervision.

- **Child behaviour and wellbeing**: Promoting healthy emotional and social development.

- **Caregiver mental health and social support**: Enhancing wellbeing through community support and self-care.

As a facilitator, your role is to guide small groups of caregivers (usually 12‚Äì15 people) through the programme.

The @global.prog_name is designed to be flexible so that you can deliver it in a way that best fits your parent group.
The programme is delivered mainly through a **WhatsApp group**. You will set up and manage the group, share the curriculum with caregivers, and lead group discussions.
When you create a parent group in the app, you will choose the age group focus: Caregivers of young children (2-9), Caregivers of teens (10-17), Caregivers of young children and teens (2-17)
The programme has **six sessions**. These can be a mix of in-person and remote (WhatsApp-based) sessions.
You and your organisation can decide which format is best for your group:
- **Onboarding only (Session 1 in person)**: Meet parents face-to-face to build trust, explain how the programme works, and practice the first skills together.

- **Closing only (Session 6 in person)**: Meet parents face-to-face at the end to reflect, celebrate progress, and encourage continued practice.
- **Both onboarding and closing (Sessions 1 & 6 in person)**: Start strong with group connection and finish with a meaningful celebration.
- **Fully remote (all sessions on WhatsApp)**: Run everything online if in-person meetings are not possible.
The core of the programme always happens in the WhatsApp group, whether or not you have in-person sessions.

The key approach to @global.prog_name is that we draw on the shared wisdom and experience of our parents to help brainstorm and problem-solve the challenges we want to tackle at home. That means that we want everybody to pool their ideas so that we all develop and practice new skills. 

Parents are welcome to share in whatever way they are most comfortable: text or audio messages. 

The foundation for this programme is the idea that parents want to strengthen their relationships with their kids in order to build a healthy home. That‚Äôs why they are here! 

The programme encourages positive interactions between parents and kids by helping parents to develop skills around praising good behaviour, spending quality time, and talking about feelings. 

If parents are spending time reinforcing positive behaviours with praise, then parents will have to do less work managing problem behaviours. 

Other skills that the programme introduces to manage unwanted behaviours include ignoring and redirecting negative attention-seeking behaviours and introducing consequences. 

The notion that children are kept safe by establishing rules and routines, planning for any risks, and surrounding them with as much care as possible underscores the entire programme.

The programme uses online messaging platforms that are familiar to parents (e.g., WhatsApp, Viber, Telegram, Facebook Messenger, etc.). 

The main teaching method in this programme is to do activities together to enable learning through doing instead of learning through being told. This method helps participants to learn both during the sessions and at home. 

This is because we all remember and understand things much better when we have done them ourselves.

- Make sure all materials and venues are prepared in advance of the session.

- Greet caregivers when they arrive at the session.

- Create a safe, comfortable and empathetic space, make them feel welcome with a smile and eye contact.

- Remember that every child develops at different speeds and stages. 

- Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values, and circumstances. 

- Encourage caregivers to share and respond to each other - and praise them when they do it!

- Remind caregivers of group rules when needed.

- Notice when a parent is quiet or struggles with something and provides support. 

- Model the behaviour you want to see among the mothers, fathers, and caregivers. 

- Use energisers to keep live interactions engaging and fun.

**Welcome and Check-in** 

Begin each session with a message that welcomes the parents to the session chat. 

Check-in to make sure that everyone is ready to begin the session. This is easier said than done when you are online! You may want to ask if that everybody‚Äôs connection is steady and that they are comfortable and sitting somewhere where they can ‚Äòchat‚Äô. 

Praise parents for making the effort to join the session and let them know you are excited to get going!

Take responsibility for ensuring that everybody‚Äôs contribution is heard. This means making sure you understand the language needs and abilities of participants before you begin ‚Äì will everybody be typing? Or will there be a mix of audio and text from parents?

Framing the session: It‚Äôs important to let parents know what to expect from each session. Start each session by letting them know what home activity are we discussing.

Ask parents how they are feeling today. You can model this process by sending a message that shares about how you are feeling today and describing where you are feeling it in your body, for example: ‚ÄúToday I am tired! I was up at night with my child. I can feel it in my sore, heavy feet, which don‚Äôt seem to want to walk anywhere very fast!‚Äù


**Checking in on home activity**
Start by reminding parents what last week‚Äôs parenting tip was. Ask a simple question to see who tried it ‚Äî like a üëç or ‚ÄúYes/Not yet.‚Äù Keep it light and supportive. Praise parents who gave it a try, even if it was just a little. Encourage those who didn‚Äôt ‚Äî remind them it‚Äôs okay to try again this week.

**Voting on a challenge to discuss** 
After checking in on the home activity, give parents a chance to vote on a common challenge they may have faced. Share 3‚Äì4 relatable options. This helps parents feel seen and makes it easy to respond.

Let them know it‚Äôs normal to face challenges ‚Äî voting creates a safe space to talk about what was hard.

**Discussing Solution** 
Before arriving at a solution, it is useful to explore the challenge in depth.

_**Tips for exploring questions and challenges**_

Use open-ended questions! So instead of saying ‚Äúdid you do this tip?‚Äù ask ‚ÄúHow did the tip work in your home?‚Äù 

Try using Who? What? When? Why? Where? And How?

Remember to redirect what the participant says to topics related to the programme.

Praise, praise, and praise some more! When you praise the parents, you demonstrate how praising works and help to promote the positive while parents are tackling challenges.

The stages of problem solving can be useful to develop a specific pool of possible solutions to the challenges that are being discussed. 

Brainstorm solutions: Start the process with a quick brainstorm for possible solutions. Invite all parents to contribute any ideas that they think will work. If they are struggling to contribute, ask them to share strategies that they have tried in their own homes. Make sure you take note of the solutions you would like to discuss further with the group.

Summarise the solutions that have been proposed.

Explore the consequences for the selected solutions: Explore solutions by inviting the group to think about the consequences of each proposed solution. This might include a child‚Äôs perspective or experience of each solution; and any feelings that it might evoke. Guide the discussion carefully so that parents have an opportunity to think through what might not work with any problematic suggestions.

Select a solution: Parents pick a solution that they want to try out at home.
‚Üí Remember to praise: Praise parents for working through a challenge and encourage them to try their solution out at home. 


**Open Feedback** 
Invite parents to share their experience from home ‚Äì ensuring that each parent that wants to share gets a chance to do so. Parents can share success stories as well as any challenges that came up while they were practicing at home. 

Connect the success to the building block for that parenting tip. This will help to remind and reinforce the building blocks for that parenting tip.

Invite the group to then discuss the challenge(s) that have been shared. Select one of the challenges shared by the parents. Follow the steps of ‚ÄúDiscussing the solution.‚Äù

Remember that parents will often expect facilitators to have all of the answers ‚Äì but parents are the experts in their own lives and have a lot of experience to draw from in sharing their own solutions. This will help circulate new ideas to the group.


**Take a Pause and Closing**

Take a Pause is an opportunity for parents to reconnect with their breathing and themselves. It‚Äôs a quiet moment at the end of the session that they can also use at home when they are feeling stressed.

Closing the session is an opportunity to pull out the most important content from the session. Most importantly, closing the session is an opportunity to tell parents what they are doing right! Thank parents for sharing and reminding them all how difficult it can be to try new things. Praise, praise, praise them for the work they are doing to make themselves and their families healthier and happier!

In some programmes, facilitators tell participants what to do and why it is important. Participants are used to this because many education systems are delivered in a didactic, teacher-knows-best manner. 

In the @global.prog_name, we do things differently. We like to think of this as a collaborative approach to learning. As facilitators, we are **collaborators or partners** working with parents to identify plans and practice solutions that will help them to improve life at home.
**It is helpful to think of the participants as the experts.**
 
Many of the parents will already be practicing lots of positive ways of parenting with their children. Others will be able to identify ways of improving their parenting on their own with guidance. **Our job is to help parents learn for themselves how to achieve their goals.**
This sometimes means we have to work harder to ask the right sort of open-ended questions that will help participants work out the benefits of positive parenting and relationship building. **When participants are able to teach themselves on how to relate and behave, they learn a skill that will help them for a long time after the programme ends.**

The modelling principle is at the foundation of how we deliver the @global.prog_name. 
If we lead sessions in a collaborative approach, praise parents often, practice active listening (by acknowledging messages), and use positive instructions, parents will do the same with their children. Likewise, if we tell parents what to do, criticize them, ignore their needs or concerns, or only say what we do not want them to do, they will do the same.

Facilitators need to model all the different Core Principles in this programme. 

For example, when you praise your participants, do not add any buts, ifs, or any other criticisms! Use transition warnings. Give positive, specific instructions that say the behaviour you want to see in the participants. Some behaviours may need to be addressed directly such as participants being offensive to an individual or the group.

Use praise to encourage participants to arrive on time for sessions, to complete their home activities, and when they accomplish something very challenging. Practice Taking a Pause to help reduce your own stress.

The participants will learn from your example and begin to mirror your behaviour, too.

**It really works!**

The first step to building healthier and happier relationships is to spend dedicated time together. When parents spend one-on-one time with their children away from work and household duties and other people, they create space to be available to their child, to get more involved in their lives, and to build trust and communication skills. A strong parent-child relationship requires spending time together in this way.

**Key building blocks for one-on-one time**

The key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

**DAY**‚Äô- Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

**PLAY** - Let them choose the activity
Tell your child or teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

**STAY** - Focus on your child or teen
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say ‚ÄúI see‚Äù to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.

Happiness, sadness, anger, disgust, surprise, and fear: We all experience emotions. Because emotions are connected to our thoughts and behaviour, they play an important role in how we make decisions. If we don‚Äôt handle emotions well, we risk making bad decisions that can affect our well-being. And when we learn how to handle our emotions, we are more likely to be able to make clear decisions and act in a responsive and nurturing way towards our children, other adults, and ourselves.

Young people who don‚Äôt manage their emotions can resort to risky behaviours that can be dangerous for them. It is important for parents to learn to help their children to recognise and manage their strong emotions. 

Talking about difficult emotions is especially important. Difficult emotions like anger can become stressful thoughts and uncontrolled behaviours. Before we can talk about the emotions we are experiencing, just being aware of them can help us to stay present in a moment, which will allow the feelings to run their course and pass. This is also true for children.

When parents name their children‚Äôs feelings, or comment on them, it helps children to develop a sense of emotional control. Parents can accept their children‚Äôs emotions and communicate with them about what they are experiencing in a calm and supportive way. This will reduce other more potentially risky ways children might turn to in order to escape the feeling.

During Module Two, parents learn about the importance of accepting, naming, and exploring a range of emotions with their children. They learn techniques that will help them to do this effectively. 

**The primary objectives for this week are parents learning and practicing how to talk about their own and their children‚Äôs feelings.**

**Key building blocks for talking about emotions**

The key building blocks for Talking about Emotions are Breathe, Share, Listen, Show, and Seek:

**BREATHE. Slowly. Pause**. 
Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out. It will calm you and give you a chance to think.

**SHARE how you feel**
This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. 

**LISTEN to your child or teen**
Allow your child to share their emotions. You can also reflect back what they say to you. Accept that the feeling is okay, even if it is negative.

**SHOW them you care**
This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our children and teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say, ‚ÄòI understand.‚Äô It can change everything.

**SEEK the positive**
Can you and your child or teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

The objective of this week is to learn how parents can be more effective at getting their children to follow their instructions. They do this in two ways: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Giving specific, positive, and realistic instructions
2Ô∏è‚É£ Praising their children for following instructions and at other times

When parents give specific, positive, and realistic instructions, children know exactly what behaviour is expected from them. 

For example, ‚ÄúPlease put your toys away in the box.‚Äù This tells the child exactly what to do by describing the behaviour that is expected. It also considers the capabilities of the child so that the instruction is realistic. 

Compare this to, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt make a mess,‚Äù which does not describe the behaviour that a parent would want to see, is not specific, and might not be realistic if the child is not capable of keeping tidy. 

Children also have challenges following many instructions at one time ‚Äì especially younger children. They are much better at following instructions if they are given one at a time.  Parents can pause for a bit to give children time to follow each instruction before moving to the next one. It may take more time, but this supports children to follow instructions and to remember the task.  

Each child has their own unique characteristics and capabilities. It is important that parents know what is realistic for their children to do when giving them instructions. For instance, it is very hard for children to keep quiet for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes while their parents take a call.  

Children also hear better and understand the instructions clearly when parents speak in a calm voice. Yelling at children only increases the tension for everyone. Children are also more likely to follow instructions in a calm way.

Praise is an expression of approval or appreciation. When parents praise their children for following instructions, they are encouraging that behaviour to happen more often. The same works for praising other behaviours. Also, behaviour that is ignored is less likely to happen again. 

With the example above, a parent could say, ‚ÄúThank you for putting your toys in the box, Joseph,‚Äù after he follows the instruction. This will encourage Joseph to continue cleaning up his toys in the future. It also maintains a positive feeling between the parent and Joseph.

Parents sometimes get frustrated at their children for being noisy or not tidying up after they have played, throwing their food on the ground, or staying out way too late. Often children don‚Äôt understand why these things are important. Establishing and explaining household rules helps children understand what is expected of them and why. Rules also establish clear boundaries that help children to feel safe and secure.

Routines also help children to feel safe and secure. Routines such as mealtimes and bedtimes can help create a stable environment for children. This is especially important for those who are living in hectic or unsafe environments and communities. 

**In this module, parents focus on the importance of involving their children when establishing household rules and routines to help keep their children safe and healthy.**

There are lots of different ways for parents to encourage their children to behave well. In this programme we have already looked at one of these ways: praising the behaviour we would like to see more of. 

In this module we look at two other strategies for managing child behaviours: Redirecting and consequences. 

Redirecting is a strategy that is especially effective with younger children. When parents redirect their children from a negative behaviour to a positive behaviour at the beginning of the behaviour, they reduce the chance that the negative behaviour happens or grows into something more difficult to manage. This works especially well if parents then praise their children for the positive behaviour they end up doing. 

Consequences are the results of actions or behaviours. For example, not cleaning the dishes will result in not having a clean plate to eat from. Parents can use planned consequences with their children and teens when they forget or do not follow household rules. For example, if there is a household rule to come home before sunset and a child comes home late when out playing with friends, then an appropriate consequence could be that they cannot play with friends the next day.

Parents can involve their children and teens in planning consequences for certain behaviours. For example, they could discuss with their children what a consequence could be if they do not follow a certain household rule when they are creating it with them. 

Consequences can also be used when a child refuses to follow an instruction. Parents should first give a child a choice, for example, ‚ÄúEither you clear the table, or you will not be able to watch your favourite T.V. show.‚Äù This gives them a chance to comply and avoid receiving the consequence.
It is also important that parents make sure their consequences are reasonable and that they can follow through with them. Banning T.V. for the rest of the year or threatening to sell it is not something that parents can realistically do. It is also unfair!

We call strategies like redirect and consequences ‚Äòpositive discipline‚Äô because they reinforce the positive relationship that parents are actively trying to build with their children by spending time together, praising and setting clear boundaries with rules.

**Key building blocks for positive discipline**

The key building blocks for Positive Discipline are Be Calm, Be Fair, and Be Positive:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Be Calm. The most important thing you can remember is to be calm when disciplining your child. Take a couple deep breaths or walk away if you need to. And then respond in a calm and clear way. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Be Fair. Give your child a choice to comply before giving a consequence. For household rules, you can discuss consequences with your child or teen in advance. Make sure the consequence is reasonable and one you can follow through on.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Be Positive. Remember the Sunshine of Positive Attention! Try to avoid giving consequences in the first place by redirecting your child and giving lots of positive attention to the behaviours you want to see more of with plenty of praise. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Catch the behaviour before it occurs or early on!

3Ô∏è‚É£ Ignore the negative behaviour, not the child.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Use physical and verbal praise to support positive behaviour.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Consequences should be specific, realistic, and reasonable.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Give a clear reason for the consequence. 

4Ô∏è‚É£ Introduce the consequence when both you and your child are calm and involve your child in deciding what the consequence should be.

5Ô∏è‚É£ When your child refuses to follow an instruction, give your child one last choice to comply before giving them a consequence.

6Ô∏è‚É£ When you give your child a consequence, you must follow through with it.

The last module of the @global.app_name programme is about reflection and sharing. This final module is a bit longer than normal as you will help parents to reflect on their experiences during the programme and make specific plans on how they want to go forward without your facilitation.

The module starts with an opportunity to learn one final parenting skill ‚Äì involving your children in solving problems. Throughout the entire programme, you have been modelling the key steps of solving problems with the parents.

There are 5 key steps in problem solving:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Identify the problem
2Ô∏è‚É£ Jointly come up with solutions
3Ô∏è‚É£ Choose a solution
4Ô∏è‚É£ Try the solution out
5Ô∏è‚É£ Reflect on whether the solution worked

Each week during the discussion on home activities and illustrated stories, the parents have used the same steps in problem solving to help identify and practice solutions to challenges experienced.

Teaching children how to solve their own problems is a skill that children will take with them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

In the second part of the module, parents have the opportunity to reflect on the changes they have seen in their families and the experiences that they have had during the programme. They can share how they have changed and what they have noticed about how their children‚Äôs behaviours may have changed.

This is also an opportunity to discuss how parents can continue using the skills and building blocks they have practiced over the course of the programme. Weekly chats have enabled parents to get to know each other and to support each other. That support doesn‚Äôt need to end! With a new administrator of the group, the chat group can be used whenever anybody needs to reach out or check-in. 

This week‚Äôs programme objectives are therefore to reflect and identify how to keep the programme going in a parent-lead group. We cover these topics for just one day this week: today!

KNOW IT. Identify the problem

SOLVE IT. Think of possible solutions and what their results would be. 

TRY IT. Choose one solution and try it out 

TEST IT. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to gently remind them of their importance. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language or is disrespectful to another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.
